concepts.concept_name: Importance of chemistry and its scope
Laws of chemical combination and Dalton's atomic theory
Atomic and molecular masses, mole concept, and Avogadro's number
Percentage composition, empirical and molecular formulae
Stoichiometry and stoichiometric calculations

in_scope: Nature of matter: elements, compounds, and mixtures
Physical and chemical properties, SI units of measurement
Uncertainty in measurement: significant figures, dimensional analysis
Law of conservation of mass (Lavoisier)
Law of definite proportions (Proust)
Law of multiple proportions (Dalton)
Gay-Lussac's law of gaseous volumes
Avogadro's law
Dalton's atomic theory and its postulates
Atomic mass unit (amu/u), average atomic mass
Molecular mass and formula mass
Mole concept: 1 mole = 6.022 x 10^23 entities
Molar mass (g/mol)
Percentage composition by mass
Empirical formula from percentage composition
Molecular formula from empirical formula and molar mass
Balanced chemical equations and stoichiometric coefficients
Mole-mole, mass-mass, and mass-volume stoichiometric calculations
Limiting reagent and excess reagent
Reactions in solutions: molarity, molality, mole fraction
Concentration terms and dilution calculations
out_of_scope: Normality and equivalent weight calculations — not in NCERT Class 11
Advanced solution thermodynamics — Class 12
Colligative properties in detail — Class 12
Radioactive decay calculations — Class 11 (Nuclear Chemistry, not basic concepts)

concepts.concept_name: Discovery of subatomic particles and early atomic models
Bohr's model of the hydrogen atom and its limitations
Quantum mechanical model: dual nature, de Broglie relation, Heisenberg uncertainty principle
Quantum numbers and shapes of orbitals
Electronic configuration: Aufbau principle, Pauli exclusion, Hund's rule

in_scope: Discovery of electron (cathode ray experiment — J.J. Thomson), charge-to-mass ratio
Discovery of proton (anode rays) and neutron (Chadwick)
Thomson's plum-pudding model
Rutherford's alpha-particle scattering experiment and nuclear model
Atomic number (Z), mass number (A), isotopes, and isobars
Electromagnetic radiation: wavelength, frequency, wave number, speed of light relation
Planck's quantum theory, E = hv
Photoelectric effect and particle nature of light
Atomic spectra: emission and absorption spectra, line spectrum of hydrogen
Bohr's model: postulates, energy of stationary states, radii of orbits
Calculation of energy and radius for hydrogen-like species
Limitations of Bohr's model
De Broglie's hypothesis: wave-particle duality, lambda = h/mv
Heisenberg's uncertainty principle: delta_x * delta_p >= h/4pi
Quantum mechanical model of atom (Schrodinger equation — conceptual, not derivation)
Quantum numbers: principal (n), azimuthal (l), magnetic (ml), spin (ms)
Shapes of s, p, and d orbitals
Energies of orbitals: (n+l) rule
Aufbau principle and the order of filling of orbitals
Pauli exclusion principle
Hund's rule of maximum multiplicity
Electronic configurations of elements up to Z = 30
Stability of half-filled and completely filled subshells (Cr, Cu anomalies)
out_of_scope: Mathematical derivation of Schrodinger wave equation
Radial and angular wave functions in detail
Relativistic effects on electron configuration — advanced
Quantum mechanics of multi-electron systems in mathematical detail
Stern-Gerlach experiment in detail

topics.topic_name: Classification of Elements and Periodicity in Properties

concepts.concept_name: Historical development of the periodic table
Modern periodic law and structure of the modern periodic table
Periodic trends: atomic and ionic radii, ionisation enthalpy, electron gain enthalpy
Electronegativity and its periodic trends
Periodic trends in chemical properties: valence, oxidation states, and anomalous properties

in_scope: Genesis of periodic classification: Dobereiner's triads, Newlands' octaves
Mendeleev's periodic table and periodic law (based on atomic mass)
Achievements and limitations of Mendeleev's periodic table
Modern periodic law: properties as periodic function of atomic number (Moseley)
Long form of the periodic table: 18 groups, 7 periods
Nomenclature of elements with Z > 100 (IUPAC system)
Classification into s-, p-, d-, and f-blocks based on electronic configuration
Metals, non-metals, metalloids, noble gases
Periodic trends in physical properties: atomic radii, ionic radii
Covalent radius, van der Waals radius
Ionisation enthalpy: definition, factors affecting, trends across period and down group
Successive ionisation enthalpies
Electron gain enthalpy: definition, trends, exceptions
Electronegativity: Pauling scale, trends across period and down group
Periodicity of valence and oxidation states
Anomalous properties of second-period elements (diagonal relationship)
Chemical reactivity trends across period and down group
out_of_scope: Allred-Rochow and Mulliken electronegativity scales — advanced
Detailed study of lanthanoids and actinoids — Class 12 (d- and f-block)
Effective nuclear charge calculations using Slater's rules — advanced
Metallic and covalent character in detail beyond periodic trends

concepts.concept_name: Ionic bonding: formation, lattice enthalpy, and properties of ionic compounds
Covalent bonding: Lewis structures, formal charge, and octet rule exceptions
VSEPR theory and molecular geometry
Hybridisation: sp, sp2, sp3, sp3d, sp3d2
Molecular orbital theory and hydrogen bonding

in_scope: Kossel-Lewis approach to chemical bonding
Octet rule and its significance
Ionic or electrovalent bond: formation by complete transfer of electrons
Lattice enthalpy and factors affecting it
Properties of ionic compounds
Born-Haber cycle (conceptual understanding)
Covalent bond: formation by sharing of electrons
Lewis dot structures of simple molecules and polyatomic ions
Formal charge calculation
Limitations of octet rule: incomplete octet, expanded octet, odd-electron species
Bond parameters: bond length, bond angle, bond enthalpy, bond order
Resonance structures and resonance energy
Polarity of bonds and dipole moment
VSEPR theory: postulates and predicting shapes of molecules
Shapes: linear, bent, trigonal planar, tetrahedral, trigonal bipyramidal, octahedral, T-shaped, see-saw, square planar, square pyramidal
Lone pair effects on bond angles
Valence bond theory: overlapping of orbitals, sigma and pi bonds
Hybridisation: sp (BeCl2), sp2 (BF3, C2H4), sp3 (CH4, NH3, H2O), sp3d (PCl5), sp3d2 (SF6)
Molecular orbital theory: LCAO method, bonding and antibonding MOs
MO diagrams for homonuclear diatomic molecules (O2, N2, etc.)
Bond order from MO theory
Magnetic properties from MO theory (paramagnetism of O2)
Hydrogen bonding: intermolecular and intramolecular, effects on properties
out_of_scope: Crystal field theory — Class 12 (Coordination Compounds)
Band theory of solids — advanced
Metallic bonding in detail (electron sea model is introductory) — advanced
Molecular orbital theory for heteronuclear diatomic molecules — advanced
Symmetry elements and point groups — advanced

concepts.concept_name: Intermolecular interactions and their effect on states of matter
Gas laws: Boyle's, Charles's, Gay-Lussac's, Avogadro's, and ideal gas equation
Kinetic molecular theory of gases
Real gases: deviations, van der Waals equation, and liquefaction
Liquid state: vapour pressure, viscosity, and surface tension

in_scope: Intermolecular forces: dispersion (London), dipole-dipole, dipole-induced dipole, hydrogen bonding
Comparison of intermolecular forces and thermal energy across states
Boyle's law: P inversely proportional to V at constant T
Charles's law: V directly proportional to T at constant P
Gay-Lussac's law: P directly proportional to T at constant V
Avogadro's law: V directly proportional to n at constant T, P
Ideal gas equation: PV = nRT, value of R in different units
Dalton's law of partial pressures
Graham's law of diffusion/effusion
Kinetic molecular theory: postulates, kinetic energy and temperature
Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution of molecular speeds (qualitative)
Root mean square speed, average speed, most probable speed
Deviation of real gases from ideal behaviour: Z (compressibility factor)
van der Waals equation: (P + a/V^2)(V - b) = RT for 1 mole
Significance of van der Waals constants a and b
Liquefaction of gases: critical temperature, critical pressure, critical volume
Andrews' isotherms of CO2 (conceptual)
Boyle temperature
Vapour pressure and its dependence on temperature
Viscosity and factors affecting it
Surface tension and factors affecting it
out_of_scope: Derivation of Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution — advanced
Virial equation of state — advanced
Solid state: crystal structures and packing — Class 12
Phase diagrams in detail — advanced
Statistical thermodynamics — advanced

concepts.concept_name: Thermodynamic terms: system, surroundings, state functions, and types of processes
First law of thermodynamics, internal energy, work, and enthalpy
Enthalpy changes: reaction enthalpy, Hess's law, and standard enthalpies
Entropy and second law of thermodynamics
Gibbs energy and spontaneity of processes

in_scope: Thermodynamic terms: system (open, closed, isolated), surroundings, boundary
State functions (P, V, T, U, H, S, G) vs path functions (q, w)
Types of processes: isothermal, adiabatic, isobaric, isochoric, reversible, irreversible
Internal energy (U) as a state function
First law: delta_U = q + w (IUPAC sign convention)
Work of expansion/compression: w = -P_ext * delta_V (irreversible), w = -nRT ln(V2/V1) (reversible isothermal)
Enthalpy (H): H = U + PV, delta_H = delta_U + delta_n_g * RT
Relationship between Cp and Cv: Cp - Cv = R (for ideal gas)
Enthalpy of reaction (delta_r H)
Standard enthalpy of formation (delta_f H°)
Standard enthalpy of combustion, neutralisation, atomisation, ionisation, lattice, hydration, solution
Bond enthalpy/bond dissociation enthalpy
Hess's law of constant heat summation
Kirchhoff's equation (qualitative — enthalpy variation with temperature)
Entropy (S): definition, entropy change for reversible process delta_S = q_rev / T
Second law: total entropy of universe always increases for spontaneous process
Gibbs energy: G = H - TS
Gibbs energy change: delta_G = delta_H - T * delta_S
Criteria for spontaneity: delta_G < 0 (spontaneous), delta_G = 0 (equilibrium), delta_G > 0 (non-spontaneous)
Gibbs energy and equilibrium constant: delta_G° = -RT ln K
Third law of thermodynamics (statement only)
out_of_scope: Statistical interpretation of entropy in detail — advanced
Carnot cycle and heat engines — Physics (Thermodynamics)
Fugacity and activity coefficients — advanced
Thermodynamics of electrochemical cells — Class 12
Detailed Kirchhoff's equation derivation and calculations — advanced

concepts.concept_name: Equilibrium in physical and chemical processes, law of mass action
Equilibrium constants (Kp, Kc), reaction quotient, and Le Chatelier's principle
Ionic equilibrium: acids, bases, and Arrhenius/Bronsted-Lowry/Lewis theories
pH, ionisation of weak acids/bases, Ka, Kb, and buffer solutions
Solubility equilibrium and solubility product (Ksp)

in_scope: Equilibrium in physical processes: solid-liquid, liquid-gas, solid-gas, dissolution of gases/solids
Dynamic nature of equilibrium
Equilibrium in chemical processes: characteristics of chemical equilibrium
Law of mass action (Guldberg and Waage)
Equilibrium constant expression: Kc (concentration), Kp (partial pressure)
Relationship between Kp and Kc: Kp = Kc(RT)^(delta_n_g)
Heterogeneous equilibrium: activities of pure solids and liquids = 1
Reaction quotient (Q) and predicting direction of reaction
Calculations involving equilibrium concentrations
Factors affecting equilibrium: Le Chatelier's principle
Effect of concentration, pressure/volume, temperature, and catalyst on equilibrium
Relationship between Gibbs energy and equilibrium constant: delta_G° = -RT ln K
Acids and bases: Arrhenius, Bronsted-Lowry, and Lewis definitions
Conjugate acid-base pairs
Ionisation of water, ionic product of water (Kw = 10^-14 at 25°C)
pH and pOH: pH = -log[H+], pH + pOH = 14
Ionisation of weak acids: Ka, degree of ionisation, Ostwald's dilution law
Ionisation of weak bases: Kb
Relationship between Ka, Kb, and Kw: Ka * Kb = Kw
Polyprotic acids and their stepwise ionisation
Buffer solutions: acidic and basic buffers, Henderson-Hasselbalch equation
Common ion effect
Hydrolysis of salts and pH of salt solutions
Solubility equilibrium: sparingly soluble salts
Solubility product (Ksp) and its relationship with solubility
Predicting precipitation using ionic product vs Ksp
out_of_scope: Activity coefficients and non-ideal solutions — advanced
Detailed titration curves and indicators theory — advanced
Equilibrium in electrochemical cells (Nernst equation) — Class 12
Distribution law / partition coefficient — advanced

concepts.concept_name: Classical concept of oxidation and reduction, and electron transfer reactions
Oxidation number: rules, calculation, and identifying redox reactions
Types of redox reactions: combination, decomposition, disproportionation
Balancing redox reactions: oxidation number method and half-reaction method

in_scope: Classical concept: oxidation as addition of oxygen/removal of hydrogen
Classical concept: reduction as removal of oxygen/addition of hydrogen
Electron transfer concept: oxidation as loss of electrons, reduction as gain of electrons
Oxidising agent (oxidant) and reducing agent (reductant)
Competitive electron transfer reactions (e.g., Zn in CuSO4 solution)
Oxidation number: definition and rules for assignment
Calculating oxidation number in molecules and ions
Identifying oxidation, reduction, oxidising agent, reducing agent using oxidation numbers
Redox reactions vs non-redox reactions
Types of redox reactions: combination, decomposition, displacement, disproportionation
Disproportionation reactions: same element is both oxidised and reduced
Balancing redox equations by oxidation number method
Balancing redox equations by half-reaction (ion-electron) method
Balancing in acidic and basic media
Redox reactions as basis of electrochemistry (conceptual link)
out_of_scope: Electrochemical cells: galvanic and electrolytic cells — Class 12
Electrode potentials, standard electrode potential, Nernst equation — Class 12
EMF of a cell and its measurement — Class 12
Faraday's laws of electrolysis — Class 12
Corrosion as electrochemical process — Class 12

concepts.concept_name: Position of hydrogen in the periodic table and its isotopes
Preparation, properties, and uses of dihydrogen
Hydrides: ionic, covalent, and interstitial
Water: structure, properties, hard and soft water
Hydrogen peroxide: preparation, properties, structure, and uses

in_scope: Position of hydrogen in periodic table: resemblance with alkali metals and halogens
Isotopes of hydrogen: protium, deuterium, tritium
Dihydrogen: occurrence in nature
Preparation of dihydrogen: laboratory methods and industrial methods (Bosch process, Lane process, steam reforming, electrolysis of water)
Physical properties of dihydrogen
Chemical properties: reaction with halogens, dioxygen, dinitrogen, metals, metal ions/oxides, organic compounds
Uses of dihydrogen: ammonia synthesis, hydrogenation, fuel cells, rocket fuel
Hydrides: classification into ionic (saline), covalent (molecular), and metallic (interstitial) hydrides
Properties of each type of hydride
Water: structure (bent shape, sp3 hybridisation), physical properties, hydrogen bonding
Amphoteric nature of water
Hard water and soft water: temporary and permanent hardness
Methods of removal of hardness: washing soda, calgon, ion exchange, distillation
Heavy water (D2O): preparation and properties
Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2): preparation, reactions (oxidising and reducing agent)
Structure of H2O2 (open book structure, non-planar)
Uses of hydrogen peroxide: bleaching, disinfectant, rocket propellant
Hydrogen as a fuel: hydrogen economy (introduction)
out_of_scope: Detailed study of deuterium compounds — advanced
Nuclear fusion involving hydrogen isotopes — advanced/Physics
Hydrogen storage technologies in detail — advanced
Metal hydride batteries — advanced

concepts.concept_name: Group 1 elements (alkali metals): electronic configuration, occurrence, and physical properties
Chemical properties and reactions of alkali metals
Important compounds of sodium and potassium
Group 2 elements (alkaline earth metals): properties and chemical reactivity
Important compounds of calcium and magnesium, anomalous behaviour of beryllium

in_scope: General introduction to s-block elements
Group 1 (alkali metals): electronic configuration, atomic and ionic radii, ionisation enthalpy
Physical properties: softness, low density, low melting points, flame colours
Chemical properties: reaction with oxygen (oxides, peroxides, superoxides)
Reaction with water, halogens, hydrogen, and liquid ammonia
Reducing nature of alkali metals
Solutions of alkali metals in liquid ammonia
Anomalous behaviour of lithium: diagonal relationship with magnesium
Sodium hydroxide (NaOH): preparation (castner-kellner cell) and properties
Sodium carbonate (Na2CO3): preparation (Solvay process) and properties
Sodium chloride and its industrial importance
Sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3): properties and uses
Potassium compounds: KOH, KCl, K2CO3
Biological importance of sodium and potassium
Group 2 (alkaline earth metals): electronic configuration, trends in properties
Chemical properties: reaction with oxygen, water, halogens, hydrogen, acids
Thermal stability of carbonates and hydroxides
Anomalous behaviour of beryllium: diagonal relationship with aluminium
Important compounds of calcium: CaO (quicklime), Ca(OH)2 (slaked lime), CaCO3, CaSO4.2H2O (gypsum), CaSO4.1/2H2O (plaster of Paris)
Portland cement (introductory)
Biological importance of magnesium and calcium
out_of_scope: Organolithium and Grignard reagents in detail — Class 12 / Organic Chemistry
Crystal structures of s-block compounds in detail — advanced
Crown ethers and their complexes with alkali metals — advanced
Industrial extraction processes in detail — advanced

concepts.concept_name: General introduction to p-block elements and Group 13 general properties
Boron: occurrence, properties, and important compounds (borax, boric acid, boron hydrides)
Aluminium: properties, reactions, and uses
Group 14 elements: general properties, carbon allotropes, and silicon
Important compounds of carbon and silicon: oxides, halides, and silicones/zeolites

in_scope: General introduction to p-block elements: electronic configuration, variation in properties
Group 13 (Boron family): electronic configuration, atomic radii, ionisation enthalpy, electronegativity
Oxidation states: +3 and +1, inert pair effect
Boron: occurrence, physical and chemical properties
Borax (Na2B4O7.10H2O): structure, properties, borax bead test
Orthoboric acid (H3BO3): structure (layered), properties
Diborane (B2H6): preparation, structure (banana bonds / 3-centre 2-electron bonds), properties
Aluminium: occurrence, extraction (Hall-Heroult process — introduction), properties
Amphoteric nature of aluminium
Aluminium compounds: Al2O3, AlCl3 (Lewis acid, dimer structure)
Anomalous behaviour of boron: diagonal relationship with silicon
Group 14 (Carbon family): electronic configuration, trends in properties
Covalent radius, ionisation enthalpy, electronegativity trends
Oxidation states: +4 and +2, inert pair effect
Allotropes of carbon: diamond, graphite, fullerenes, carbon nanotubes (introductory)
Carbon monoxide (CO): preparation, properties (toxicity, reducing agent), structure
Carbon dioxide (CO2): preparation, properties, structure
Silicon dioxide (SiO2): structure, properties, comparison with CO2
Silicones: general structure and uses
Silicates: classification (ortho, pyro, cyclic, chain, sheet, 3D framework)
Zeolites: structure and uses (molecular sieves, catalysts)
Anomalous behaviour of carbon (compared to Si, Ge, Sn, Pb)
out_of_scope: Detailed study of Group 13 and 14 elements beyond boron, aluminium, carbon, and silicon — advanced
Semiconductor physics of silicon and germanium — Physics
Organometallic compounds of Group 13 and 14 — advanced
Detailed study of tin and lead chemistry — advanced

topics.topic_name: Organic Chemistry: Some Basic Principles and Techniques

concepts.concept_name: General introduction, classification, and IUPAC nomenclature of organic compounds
Isomerism: structural isomerism and stereoisomerism
Electronic effects: inductive, resonance, hyperconjugation, and electromeric effects
Reaction intermediates: carbocations, carbanions, free radicals, and carbenes
Methods of purification and qualitative/quantitative analysis of organic compounds

in_scope: General introduction: tetravalency of carbon, shapes of organic molecules
Classification of organic compounds: open chain (acyclic) and cyclic (homocyclic, heterocyclic)
Functional groups and homologous series
IUPAC nomenclature: rules for naming alkanes, alkenes, alkynes, and simple functional group compounds
Common (trivial) names of important organic compounds
Structural isomerism: chain, position, functional group, metamerism, tautomerism
Stereoisomerism: geometrical (cis-trans) isomerism
Optical isomerism (chirality, enantiomers, diastereomers — introduction)
Electronic displacement in covalent bonds
Inductive effect: +I and -I groups, applications
Resonance (mesomeric) effect: +R and -R groups, resonance structures
Hyperconjugation (no-bond resonance): sigma-pi conjugation
Electromeric effect
Homolytic and heterolytic bond fission
Reactive intermediates: carbocations (stability order), carbanions, free radicals, carbenes
Types of organic reactions: substitution, addition, elimination, rearrangement
Nucleophiles and electrophiles
Purification methods: crystallisation, distillation (simple, fractional, steam, vacuum), differential extraction, chromatography (column, TLC, paper, gas)
Qualitative analysis: detection of C, H, N, S, halogens (Lassaigne's test)
Quantitative estimation: C and H (Liebig's method), N (Dumas, Kjeldahl), halogens (Carius), S, P
out_of_scope: Detailed conformational analysis — advanced
R/S nomenclature and CIP priority rules in depth — advanced/Class 12
Spectroscopic methods (UV, IR, NMR, Mass spectrometry) — advanced
Detailed mechanism of each reaction type — covered in hydrocarbons chapter

concepts.concept_name: Alkanes: preparation, properties, and conformations
Alkenes: preparation, properties, and addition reactions
Alkynes: preparation, properties, and acidic character of terminal alkynes
Aromatic hydrocarbons: benzene, aromaticity, and electrophilic aromatic substitution
Directive effects in monosubstituted benzene and carcinogenicity/toxicity

in_scope: Classification of hydrocarbons: saturated, unsaturated, aromatic
Alkanes: general formula CnH2n+2, sp3 hybridisation
Preparation of alkanes: Wurtz reaction, decarboxylation, Kolbe electrolysis, hydrogenation of unsaturated hydrocarbons
Physical properties of alkanes: boiling points, solubility
Conformations of ethane: staggered and eclipsed (Newman projections)
Chemical properties of alkanes: combustion, halogenation (free radical mechanism), controlled oxidation, isomerisation, aromatisation
Alkenes: general formula CnH2n, sp2 hybridisation
Preparation of alkenes: dehydration of alcohols, dehydrohalogenation, dehalogenation
Saytzeff's rule (Zaitsev's rule)
Physical and chemical properties of alkenes
Addition reactions: hydrogenation, halogenation, hydrohalogenation (Markownikoff's and anti-Markownikoff's rule / peroxide effect), hydration
Ozonolysis of alkenes
Oxidation: KMnO4 (Baeyer's test), OsO4
Polymerisation of alkenes (introduction)
Alkynes: general formula CnH2n-2, sp hybridisation
Preparation of alkynes: from calcium carbide, dehydrohalogenation of vicinal dihalides
Physical and chemical properties of alkynes: similar addition reactions as alkenes
Acidic character of terminal alkynes (C-H acidity), reaction with Na, NaNH2, ammoniacal AgNO3, ammoniacal Cu2Cl2
Aromatic hydrocarbons: benzene, Kekule structure, resonance
Aromaticity: Huckel's rule (4n + 2 pi electrons)
Preparation of benzene (from phenol, sodium benzoate, acetylene trimerisation)
Electrophilic aromatic substitution: nitration, halogenation, sulphonation, Friedel-Crafts alkylation and acylation
Mechanism of electrophilic substitution (arenium ion mechanism)
Directive influence of functional groups: ortho/para directors and meta directors
Activating and deactivating groups
Carcinogenicity and toxicity of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons
out_of_scope: Detailed orbital symmetry and Woodward-Hoffmann rules — advanced
Heterocyclic aromatic compounds in detail — advanced
Nucleophilic aromatic substitution (SNAr) — advanced
Named reactions beyond the syllabus (Birch reduction, Diels-Alder for aromatics) — advanced
Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon synthesis — advanced

concepts.concept_name: Environmental pollution: air pollution, types of pollutants, and smog
Ozone layer depletion and acid rain
Greenhouse effect and global warming
Water pollution and soil pollution
Green chemistry: principles and strategies for waste prevention

in_scope: Environmental pollution: definition and types
Atmospheric pollution: tropospheric and stratospheric
Tropospheric pollutants: gaseous (oxides of sulphur, nitrogen, carbon; hydrocarbons) and particulate
Classical smog (London smog) and photochemical smog (Los Angeles smog)
Formation and effects of photochemical smog
Acid rain: causes (SO2, NOx), effects on environment, monuments, aquatic life
Ozone: formation in the stratosphere, Chapman cycle
Ozone layer depletion: role of CFCs, NO, Freons
Effects of ozone depletion: UV radiation and health hazards
Greenhouse effect: greenhouse gases (CO2, CH4, N2O, CFCs, water vapour)
Global warming: causes, effects, and mitigation strategies
Water pollution: causes (pathogens, organic waste, chemical pollutants, heavy metals)
Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) as indicator of water quality
Chemical Oxygen Demand (COD)
Eutrophication: causes and effects
International standards for drinking water (WHO guidelines — introductory)
Soil pollution: pesticides (DDT, BHC), industrial waste, agrochemicals
Bioaccumulation and biomagnification of pesticides
Green chemistry: definition, goals, and twelve principles (introductory)
Green chemistry in day-to-day life: use of H2O2 for bleaching, replacing halogenated solvents
Strategies for pollution control and waste minimisation
out_of_scope: Detailed quantitative analysis of pollutant concentrations — advanced
Water treatment plant operations in detail — engineering
Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) procedures — advanced/policy
Detailed atmospheric chemistry and reaction kinetics — advanced
Environmental legislation and policies — non-chemistry
